Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2012 11:49AM KTGR wrote: I just went through the same thing. I was birad 5. Had both a core needle biopsy and then, because the findings came back benign but discordant, had an excisional biopsy. It has turned out to be a benign radial scar. Don't freak out. Really. I did, but then I did things to comfort myself: walking, baths, eating really well, reading, meditating, and yes, crying. I have three girls, a 10 year old, and two 4 year olds. One of my twins has cerebral palsy. Bad things float through your mind; let them float OUT of your mind. Don't get ahead of yourself. Birad 4a odds are really good to be benign. Deep breaths. Take care of business and take care of yourself.
Posts.Title: BiRads 4a, Waiting for Biopsy FrayedKnot lisabdcat

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2014 03:13PM KTGR wrote: I had the very same thing. Architectural distortion, with a BIRAD 5. I had a core needle biopsy, for which the results turned out to be discordant with the radiologists finding. So I had the lesion removed. It was a B9 radial scar. I have three daughters. I too was so, so worried. Hang in there. It could be something, but there are cases when it's B9.
Posts.Title: Scared - Please Help MOchsner Ksk04

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2013 07:30PM KTGR wrote: Hi, there: about a month ago I had the same thing happen to me, only I was Birad 5, which in radiology speak means it is likely 95% cancer. It turned out to be benign, a radial scar, but i had to have it removed with an excisional biopsy to find out. So, with you being in the Birad 3 category on mammogram and ultrasound, I would say there is a high likelihood of your lump being B9 based on statistics associated with those scores. Even a Birad 4 is often benign, but still needs to be biopsied. The problem with an MRI is that is is highly sensitive yet not specific, and there are a lot of false positives. It's a great tool, but not perfect. I would try to take a deep breath, know that the odds are in your favor, and go one step at a time. Good luck. Karen
Posts.Title: Mammotome tomorrow Grace10 KTGR

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2013 07:56PM KTGR wrote: I have dense breasts too, had a 3D mammogram, was called back and was told I was a Birad 5, which means highly likely it's cancer, 95%. It wasn't. It was a b9 radial scar. I had a core needle biopsy, which turned out to show fibro-cystic changes, stromal fibrosis and one other B9 finding. However, because what the CNB found did not explain the Birad 5 concerns, it was called discordant and I had to have an excisional biopsy. Both radiologists who saw my mammogram, ultrasound and biopsy report still felt that I had cancer before the excisional biopsy. Sometimes they're wrong, but I am grateful that they were so diligent. Your doc may or may not be wrong (but she might). I felt the fear you feel now. I hope the absolute best for you. Take care and take one step at a time.
Posts.Title: Don't know what to think Nellie5 Homebody

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2014 11:25PM KTGR wrote: I had a completely B9 radial scar removed during an excisional biopsy. I think talking to a second surgeon might put your mind at ease. Good luck.
Posts.Title: radial scar and very confused katiedaw KTGR

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2013 03:44AM KTGR wrote: I am a little older than you, 46, and also have lumpy, dense breasts. I had an excisional biopsy done on a lesion caught  by 3d mammogram. It turned out to be a B9 radial scar. However, I am being followed by a breast specialist and was told that my risk is higher than average for developing breast cancer. I'm happy to have a specialist following me. Perhaps a meeting with a breast surgeon/ specialist would help you and he/she would be able to address your concerns.
